title: How to Make Sugar Mice

steps.headline: Put one half of the sugar, lightly beaten egg white or substitute, and golden syrup into a mixing bowl.
Mix together until smooth.
steps.description: Add the rest of the sugar and mix through.

steps.headline: Remove the mixture from the bowl and roll out the dough on a clean surface.
steps.description: Dust the surface with cornflour and icing sugar. After rolling out, divide the fondant into eight even portions.

steps.headline: Shape the mice.
steps.description: Remove a small piece of the fondant for the ears. Roll the rest of the piece into a ball, then push it down to form a length (the mouse body). At one end shape a sharper point to create the nose and head shape. At the other end, keep the rounded ball shape - you will be attaching a ribbon tail here. Press in the two small confectionery balls to serve as eyes.

steps.headline: Shape the ears.
steps.description: Make two little rounded shapes with a hollowed middle part, just like real mouse ears. Use a toothpick to help shape and to make insertion holes in the head part of the mouse. Press in the ears and close the fondant around the ear base to hold in place.

steps.headline: Push in the tail.
steps.description: Cut a length of thin ribbon in to form the tail. Alternatively, use a length of licorice or other long candy piece. Or, as in the image above, use a stick for the tail.

steps.headline: Cover a tray with baking paper.
steps.description: Put the eight mice onto the tray. Cover with another sheet of paper (wax paper is a good choice as it is slightly heavier and less inclined to blow off). Put the tray in a dry, warm place to dry the mice. Leave for 48 hours.

steps.headline: Wrap each mouse individually in clear cellophane and tie at each end with thin ribbon or raffia.
steps.description: The mice are now ready for sale.

text: Put one half of the sugar, lightly beaten egg white or substitute, and golden syrup into a mixing bowl.  Mix together until smooth. Add the rest of the sugar and mix through. Remove the mixture from the bowl and roll out the dough on a clean surface. Dust the surface with cornflour and icing sugar. After rolling out, divide the fondant into eight even portions. Shape the mice. Remove a small piece of the fondant for the ears. Roll the rest of the piece into a ball, then push it down to form a length (the mouse body). At one end shape a sharper point to create the nose and head shape. At the other end, keep the rounded ball shape - you will be attaching a ribbon tail here. Press in the two small confectionery balls to serve as eyes. Shape the ears. Make two little rounded shapes with a hollowed middle part, just like real mouse ears. Use a toothpick to help shape and to make insertion holes in the head part of the mouse. Press in the ears and close the fondant around the ear base to hold in place. Push in the tail. Cut a length of thin ribbon in to form the tail. Alternatively, use a length of licorice or other long candy piece. Or, as in the image above, use a stick for the tail. Cover a tray with baking paper. Put the eight mice onto the tray. Cover with another sheet of paper (wax paper is a good choice as it is slightly heavier and less inclined to blow off). Put the tray in a dry, warm place to dry the mice. Leave for 48 hours. Wrap each mouse individually in clear cellophane and tie at each end with thin ribbon or raffia. The mice are now ready for sale.
